A hasty engineer used Blum integers for the public key in their RSA-encrypted message: 1371612457568535465650048865946885006884983968810756868563510364589937225046612465501758626044782741696236303319427347378204030045474524914906095839336704. Can you exploit the weakness to recover the secret?

The flag format is flag{...}
n=6933348592198809532814380629863569319448919308869968165074644773258266204409460226027183354261003363375874134724348780133680638718290472121819980504345721, e=6908212999102647721513887678379532478089575815389237202787397078372506338122089723592011006923729009011405598101515734842571203021508664896067321120713131
The lower 104 bits of p are: 60020772189032944406239873157671105179


---

## Challenge Technical Details
flag: flag{zx447aui}
cipher: RSA
ciphertext: 1371612457568535465650048865946885006884983968810756868563510364589937225046612465501758626044782741696236303319427347378204030045474524914906095839336704
vulnerability: blum integers
hint: Blum integers are products of primes congruent to 3 modulo 4. These integers have unique properties in cryptography.
necessary_info: The flag format is flag{...}
n=6933348592198809532814380629863569319448919308869968165074644773258266204409460226027183354261003363375874134724348780133680638718290472121819980504345721, e=6908212999102647721513887678379532478089575815389237202787397078372506338122089723592011006923729009011405598101515734842571203021508664896067321120713131
The lower 104 bits of p are: 60020772189032944406239873157671105179

extra_info: p=71558160981537397569266123556066400289679564829657357386124293139633595429531, q=96891095258689938994574456274786470105332760780095542172311484078948177466491, Ï†(n)=6933348592198809532814380629863569319448919308869968165074644773258266204409291776770943126924439522796043281853953767808070885818732036344601398731449700
